content: Indonesian chicken soup **Soto ayam** is a traditional [Indonesian dish](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine) with ingredients such as chicken, *[lontong](/wiki/Lontong)*, [noodles](/wiki/Noodles), and [rice vermicelli](/wiki/Rice_vermicelli). Soto ayam is also popular in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia) and [Suriname](/wiki/Suriname), where it is made with slightly different ingredients and known as saoto. [Turmeric](/wiki/Turmeric) is added as one of its main ingredients which makes the yellow chicken broth. It is one of the most popular variants of *[soto](/wiki/Soto_(food))*, a traditional soup commonly found in [Indonesian cuisine](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine). Besides chicken and vermicelli can also be served with hard-boiled [eggs](/wiki/Egg_(food)), slices of fried potatoes, and [Chinese celery](/wiki/Leaf_celery) leaves. Fried [shallots](/wiki/Shallot) are usually added as a [garnish](/wiki/Garnish_(food)). [Coconut milk](/wiki/Coconut_milk) (*santan*) is also used as an additional ingredient. *Koya*, a powder of mixed prawn crackers with fried garlic, or [sambal](/wiki/Sambal) is a common topping. *[Krupuk](/wiki/Krupuk)* or *[emping](/wiki/Emping)* is also a common topping. [Lalapan](/wiki/Lalab) is usually served as a side dish. ## Variations Different regions have their variation of this dish, for instance: - Soto Ambengan, originated from Ambengan, [Surabaya](/wiki/Surabaya).
